Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2016 IEEE International Conference on Computer Communications (IEEE INFOCOM)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: The IEEE International Conference on Computer Communications (INFOCOM) is a preeminent venue for world-leading scientists, researchers, and practitioners to present the latest research results and to exchange research ideas over a broad range of topics in computer communications and networking. Attending this conference is of paramount importance for the career development of students in the field. It provides students with opportunities to present their work, to learn the cutting-edge research, and to interact with leading experts and fellow students from worldwide institutions. This award will support approximately 25 students in the United States to attend the 2016 IEEE INFOCOM conference which will be held in San Francisco, CA, USA from April 10 to April 15, 2016. The travel grants will target graduate students, in particular female and underrepresented minority students. Priority will be given to the students who will substantially benefit from attending this conference but have limited travel funds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project provided travel support for 34 graduate students based in the United States to attend the 2016 IEEE International Conference on Computer Communications (IEEE INFOCOM), which was held in San Francisco, CA, USA from April 10 to April 15, 2016. This preeminent technical conference is the primary venue for presenting new research results in the area of computer communications, and is widely attended by leading scientists, researchers and practitioners from all around the world. The INFOCOM 2016 had 888 participants from 46 countries, and 400 participants were from US. Attending such a high-caliber conference is extremely valuable for graduate students’ education and long-term career development. By providing the travel support, this project contributes to the training of the future researchers in the field of computer communications and networking.

The travel support is critical for many graduate students to attend the INFOCOM 2016, especially for the students from the East Coast and the students facing financial challenges. Among all the applicants, 82% were selected to receive the travel support, with priorities given to women, under-represented minority students, and students who would substantially benefit from attending the conference. Out of the 34 awardees from 18 states and 33 universities, 5 are female students, two thirds are in the middle of their doctoral program, and many are first-time attendees.

The awardees expressed their deep appreciation for the NSF travel support and acknowledged the great value and importance of attending the conference. They not only had the opportunities of presenting their work, learning the state-of-the-art research, participating panel discussions, but also were able to meet new colleagues, and interact with hundreds of others performing cutting-edge research in the field.

 


Last Modified: 05/17/2017
Modified by: Zhaohui Wang
